title: Domain 2.4: Explain common social-engineering attacks, threats, and vulnerabilities.
content:
ðŸ§  Social Engineering Attacks

  • Phishing: Deceptive emails or websites that steal personal info like passwords or credit cards.
  • Vishing: Phone-based phishing that tricks users into revealing sensitive info.
  • Shoulder Surfing: Observing someone to get private info like PINs or passwords.
  • Whaling: Spear-phishing targeting executives (e.g., CEO/CFO) for sensitive company info.
  • Tailgating: Unauthorized access by following someone into a secure area.
  • Impersonation: Pretending to be someone else (e.g., IT staff) to access restricted data or areas.
  • Dumpster Diving: Searching trash for confidential data like passwords or sensitive docs.
  • Evil Twin: Fake Wi-Fi hotspot designed to steal data from connected users.

ðŸš¨ Cyber Threats

  • DDoS: Overwhelms a system with traffic from multiple sources to crash or slow it down.
  • DoS: Same goal as DDoS but from one source â€” flood with traffic to make it unusable.
  • Zero-Day: Exploits an unknown vulnerability before a patch is available.
  • Spoofing: Masquerading as a trusted source (IP/email/site) to steal info or trick users.
  • On-path Attack: Intercepts data between two parties without them knowing (MITM).
  • Brute-Force: Trying all possible password combos until one works â€” slow but effective.
  • Dictionary Attack: Uses a list of common words to guess passwords faster than brute force.
  • Insider Threat: Threat comes from within the organization (employee/contractor misuse).
  • SQL Injection: Inserts malicious SQL into forms or URLs to manipulate databases.
  • XSS: Injects malicious scripts into web pages to steal user data or hijack sessions.

ðŸ”“ Vulnerabilities

  • Non-compliant Systems: Don't meet required security standards â€” easily exploitable.
  • Unpatched Systems: Miss critical updates, leaving known holes open to attackers.
  • Unprotected Systems: Lacking antivirus/firewall â€” high risk for malware and intrusions.
  • EOL Operating Systems: No longer supported or updated â€” major security holes.
  • BYOD: Personal devices used at work â€” difficult to secure and manage consistently.
